revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1739|literature|poetry}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1739'''.
==Events== *[[January 16]] – First performance of [[George Frideric Handel]]'s [[oratorio]] ''[[Saul (Handel)|Saul]]'' at the [[Her Majesty's Theatre|King's Theatre, Haymarket, London]].<ref name="Cassell's Chronology">{{cite book|last=Williams|first=Hywel|title=Cassell's Chronology of World History|location=London|publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson|year=2005|isbn=0-304-35730-8}}</ref> *[[February 9]] – ''[[The Scots Magazine]]'' is first issued.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOLM-Brl72kC&pg=PA614 |first=A. W.|last=Ward|title=The Cambridge History of English Literature|volume=9|year=2009|page=614}}</ref> *February – [[George Whitefield]] first preaches in the open air, to miners at [[Kingswood, South Gloucestershire]], England. *April – [[John Wesley]] first preaches in the open air, at Whitefield's invitation. *[[Henry Brooke (writer)|Henry Brooke]]'s drama ''Gustavus Vasa'' is the first play banned under the [[Licensing Act 1737|Licensing Act of 1737]]. *The first Bible in [[Estonian language|Estonian]], ''Piibli Ramat'', translated by [[Anton thor Helle]], is published.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Penelope Aubin]] – ''A Collection of Entertaining Histories and Novels'' *[[John Campbell (author)|John Campbell]] – ''The Travels and Adventures of Edward Bevan, Esq., formerly a merchant in London'' *[[Elizabeth Carter]] **''Examination of Mr. Pope's Essay on Man'' (translation of [[Jean-Pierre de Crousaz|De Crousaz]]'s ''Examen de l'essai de Monsieur Pope sur l'homme'') **''Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy Explain'd for the Use of Ladies'' (translation of [[Francesco Algarotti|Algarotti]]'s ''Newtonianismo per le donne'') *[[Philip Doddridge]] – ''The Family Expositor'' *[[Henry Fielding]] (as Captain Hercules Vinegar) – ''The Champion'' (periodical) *[[Richard Glover (poet)|Richard Glover]] – ''London'' *[[David Hume]] (anonymously) – ''[[A Treatise of Human Nature]]'' (issued late 1738 but dated this year) *[[William Law]] – ''The Grounds and Reasons of Christian Regeneration'' *[[John Mottley]] (as Elijah Jenkins) – ''[[Joe Miller (actor)|Joe Miller]]'s Jests; or, the Wits Vade-Mecum'' *[[Robert Nugent, 1st Earl Nugent|Robert Nugent]] (attributed) – ''An Epistle to Sir Robert Walpole'' *[[John Oldmixon]] – ''The History of England during the Reigns of Henry VIII, Edward VI, Queen Mary, Queen Elizabeth'' *[[Laetitia Pilkington]] – ''The Statues'' *[[Samuel Richardson]] – ''Aesop's Fables'' *[[Elizabeth Rowe]] – ''Miscellaneous Works'' *[[Thomas Sheridan (actor)|Thomas Sheridan]] – ''The Satires of Juvenal Translated'' *[[Joseph Trapp]] – ''The Nature, Folly, Sin, and Danger, of Being Righteous Over-much'' (against [[George Whitefield]]) *[[Voltaire]] **''De la Gloire, ou entretien avec un Chinois'' **''Conseils a M. Helvetius'' *[[Isaac Watts]] – ''The World to Come'' *[[George Whitefield]] – ''A Continuation of the Reverend Mr. Whitefield's Journal'' *[[Paul Whitehead]] – ''Manners''
===Drama=== *[[Daniel Bellamy, the younger|Daniel Bellamy]] – ''Miscellanies in Prose and Verse'' *[[Henry Brooke (writer)|Henry Brooke]] – ''Gustavus Vasa'' *[[Henry Carey (writer)|Henry Carey]] – ''Nancy'' (opera) *[[Thomas Cooke (author)|Thomas Cooke]] – ''The Mournful Nuptials'' (not acted) *[[David Mallet (writer)|David Mallet]] – ''Mustapha'' *James Miller – ''An Hospital for Fools'' *Edward Phillips – ''Britons, Strike Home'' *[[William Shirley]] – ''The Parricide'' *[[James Thomson (poet)|James Thomson]] – ''Edward and Eleonara''
===Poetry=== *[[Moses Browne]] – ''Poems'' *[[Mary Collier]] – ''The Woman's Labour: an epistle to Mr [[Stephen Duck]]'' *[[Mikhail Lomonosov]] – ''Ode on the Taking of Khotin from the Turks'' *[[Robert Nugent, 1st Earl Nugent|Robert Nugent]] **''An Ode on Mr. Pulteney'' **''An Ode, to His Royal Highness on His Birthday'' **''Odes and Epistles'' *[[Jonathan Swift]] – ''Verses on the Death of Dr. Swift'' *[[John Wesley]] – ''Hymns and Sacred Poems''
==Births== *January – [[Twm o'r Nant]], Welsh playwright and poet (died [[1810 in literature|1810]]) *[[August 31]] – [[Johann Augustus Eberhard]], German theologian and philosopher (died [[1809 in literature|1809]]) *[[November 20]] – [[Jean-François de la Harpe]], French critic (died [[1803 in literature|1803]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Hugh Kelly (poet)|Hugh Kelly]], Irish-born dramatist and poet (died [[1777 in literature|1777]])
==Deaths== *[[June 20]] – [[Edmond Martène]], French historian (born [[1654 in literature|1654]]) *[[July 25]] – [[Johann Christoph Wolf]], German Hebrew scholar and bibliographer (born [[1683 in literature|1683]]) *[[September 4]] – [[George Lillo]], English dramatist and actor (born [[1691 in literature|1691]]) *[[October 18]] – [[António José da Silva]], Brazilian dramatist (born [[1705 in literature|1705]]) *''Probable year of death'' – [[Liu Zhi (scholar)|Liu Zhi]] (劉智), Chinese Muslim scholar (born c. 1660)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authoritycontrol}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1739 In Literature}} [[Category:1739 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Steven Rooster|Steven Rooster]] ([[User talk:Steven Rooster|talk]]) to last version by Betty Logan
/* Exhibitions, lectures, and performances */ correcting name of museum
revision.text:
'''ART/MEDIA''' was a [[social sculpture]] project in the form of series of socio-political public art events that took place in 1986 in [[Albuquerque]] and [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]] [[New Mexico]].<ref name="High Performance">{{cite journal|author=Durland, Steven|title='Subersive Acts: ART/MEDIA offer an alternative to the status quo in New Mexico'|journal=High Performance Magazine|year=1986|issue= 33|pages=35–37}}</ref> This groundbreaking artist forum featured artworks presented to the public through the [[mass media]] in a series of artist-designed billboards, television, radio and print media, and in museum exhibitions, a lecture series, and [[performance art]] series.<ref name="High Performance"/> Through this extended format, the artwork and ideas of contemporary artists were made accessible to a large public audience outside of the traditional art audience.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Artweek|title='Media: Subversion and Manipulation'|journal=Artweek|date=February 1, 1986}}</ref> [[File:Steina-and-Woody-1986.jpg|thumb|Steina and Woody Vasulka, who video documented ART/MEDIA, speaking in their studio on the role of art in contemporary society. 1986]] [[File:Jenny Holzer 1986.jpg|thumb|Jenny Holzer interviewed in New Mexico on artists working with the Mass Media. 1986. Still from video by Steina & Woody Vasulka, used with permission.]]
==Social sculpture and political art==
Local and nationally known artists were commissioned to create socio-political artwork presented through the mass media, concerning critical issues of the time, such as [[nuclear proliferation]], [[environmental degradation]], [[human rights]], [[animal rights]], and loss of privacy through technology. The forum stimulated discourse between local communities and nationally known artists through hands-on video workshops, interviews, lectures, performances, informal discussions and [[road trips]].<ref name="Albuquerque Journal Magazine">{{cite journal|last=Walton|first=Marcus|title='Art and the Media: An art project adopts techniques of the mass media'|journal=Albuquerque Journal Magazine, Impact|date=January 28, 1986|volume= 9| issue = 15}}</ref> It was sponsored by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], Albuquerque Arts Alliance, the Santa Fe Center for Contemporary Art, and the New Mexico Arts Division.<ref name="Albuquerque Living Magazine">{{cite journal|last=Clancy|first=Patrick|author2=Widmer, Gwenn|title='Front Pages, Frontier Living: Disappearing Space (Even in the West)'|journal=Albuquerque Living Magazine|date=January 1986}}</ref> ART/MEDIA operated as a ''museum without walls'' with an office located in the historical [[Kimo Theater]] on [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]].<ref name="Albuquerque Living Magazine"/> Inspired by the concept/model of [[Joseph Beuys]] [[social sculpture]], that have the potential to transform society, ART/MEDIA was an extended artwork that included human interactions, creating structures and systems within society using language, thought, objects, events and actions.<ref name="The Santa Fe Reporter">{{cite news|title='Beyond the Andrews (on Paul Bob)'|newspaper=The Santa Fe Reporter|date=February 12, 1986}}</ref> The project was documented by seminal video artists [[Steina and Woody Vasulka]] who founded [[The Kitchen]] in [[New York City]] in 1971.<ref name="City Arts">{{cite journal|title='ART/MEDIA Funded by National Endowment for the Arts and New Mexico Arts Division'|journal=City Arts|date=November–December 1985}}</ref>
==Artists involved==
Artists involved in ART/MEDIA included: [[Hans Haacke]], [[Jenny Holzer]], [[Rachel Rosenthal]], [[Terry Allen (artist)]], Paul Bob of Bob and Bob, [[Church of the SubGenius]], [[Godfrey Reggio]] and the [[Qatsi_trilogy|Institute for Regional Education]], Mohammed Jim 5X (Jim Stuber), Larry Goodell, Violet Ray, Bob Willis, The Carcass Sisters, Jean-Paul Curtay, Lousie Maffitt and Robert McDermott, Patrick Clancy and [[Gwen Widmer]], Lee Connor, Barbara Bock, Manny Rettinger, John P. McCloskey, Steven Durland of [[High Performance Magazine]], and the art critic/historian, [[Craig Owens (critic)]].<ref name="Albuquerque Tribune">{{cite news|last=Raether|first=Keith|title='True Grit'|newspaper=Albuquerque Tribune|date=February 1986}}</ref><ref name="Southwest Art Magazine">{{cite journal|last=Durfee|first=Roy|title='ART/MEDIA'|journal=Southwest Art Magazine|date=March 1986|pages=20–21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bradbury|first=Ellen|title='Putting Art Where the Public Cannot Avoid It'|newspaper=Albuquerque Journal|date=February 1986}}</ref>
==Works in the mass media==
Artist-designed billboards included a series of forty billboards by [[Jenny Holzer]] addressing [[Ronald Reagan]]'s [[Strategic Defense Initiative]], and deployed a fleet of Holzer's ''Inflammatory Statements'' street posters. [[Rachel Rosenthal]] designed a billboard dealing with [[animal rights]] for laboratory rats. Paul Bob designed a series of billboards on the practice of everyday life.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shields|first=Kathleen|title='Exhibit Harks Back to Conceptual Art'|newspaper=Albuquerque Journal|date=January 19, 1986}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=de Certeau|first=Michel|title=The Practice of Everyday Life|year=1984|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, California|isbn=9780520271456}}</ref> Artist-designed print media projects included a color spread by Patrick Clancy and Gwen Widmer that recontextualized articles within Albuquerque Magazine, [[Jenny Holzer]] produced a large print piece containing her ''inflammatory statements'' that was inserted into the Sunday edition of the Albuquerque Journal newspaper, Paul Bob, and [[Rachel Rosenthal]] produced projects in other statewide publications.
==Exhibitions, lectures, and performances==
Exhibitions included ''Subversive Acts: Artists Working With The Media Politically'', at the [[New Mexico Museum of Art]] at the [[University of New Mexico]] Art Museum,<ref>{{cite news|last=Richardson|first=John|title='Subversive Acts: Daring works overthrow traditional ideas of art'|newspaper=Albuquerque Tribune|date=February 1986}}</ref> and the Art Gallery Fogelson Library Center at the College of Santa Fe.<ref>{{cite news|title='New Tools of the Trade'|newspaper=The Santa Fe Reporter|date=January 22, 1986}}</ref> ''Subversive Acts'' was an exhibition of mass media forms utilized by artists to present their sociological, environmental and political messages.<ref>{{cite news|last=Groves|first=Bob|title='Avant Garde Artists Subvert Media'|newspaper=Albuquerque Journal|date=January 5, 1986}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title='Sign Language'|journal=Route 66|issue=Dec 86/Jan 87|pages=35}}</ref><ref>Lippard, Lucy R.Undermining: A Wild RIde in Words and Images through Land Use in the Changing West, The New Press. 2014 {{ISBN|1595586199}}</ref> The video exhibition ''Tuning In'', took place at the Museum of Fine Arts, Santa Fe, and the Art Gallery of the College of Santa Fe.<ref>{{cite news|last=Clemmer|first=David J.|title='Art/Media project takes art to the masses'|newspaper=New Mexico Daily Lobo|date=February 26, 1986}}</ref> Public performances included visual artist and country western singer, [[Terry Allen (artist)]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Richardson|first=John|title='Good 'ol boy Terry Allen makes art out of everything'|journal=Time Out|date=January 31, 1986|pages=6}}</ref> performance artist and ecological activist [[Rachel Rosenthal]], Paul Bob of the performance due Bob and Bob and performance poet, Larry Goodell.<ref>{{cite news|last=Morris|first=David|title=ART/MEDIA Exhibits Political Art|newspaper=New Mexico Daily Lobo|date=January 28, 1986}}</ref> Public lectures included [[Hans Haacke]] on art, economics and ethics, [[Jenny Holzer]] speaking on the power of public art interventions to change human consciousness, [[Steven Durland]] on the history of [[performance art]], [[Craig Owens (critic)]] of Art in America Magazine speaking on the relationship between political art and the mass media.
==History==
The concept for the project originated in 1984 with artists Duane Griffin, Patrick Clancy and Scott Portman who later joined with Co-Directors [[Eve Andree Laramee]] and Ann Zimmerman to found the project and organization. The [[Santa Fe Center for Contemporary Arts]] was the fiscal sponsor under 501c3 not-for-profit status. Bob Gaylor, then director of SFCCC and invited Griffin and Laramee to be part of a [[Think Tank]] at [[St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)|St. John's College]] where they met with [[Steina and Woody Vasulka]], [[Allan Kaprow]], [[Carolee Schneemann]], [[Edward "Ned" Hall]], [[Jerome Rothenberg]], and other artists and thinkers. Empowered by this experience, a team of advisors were assembled. Gaylor served as a primary advisor throughout the project, along with Gordon Church of the City of Albuquerque Cultural Affairs Office. The Albuquerque Arts Alliance and the City of [[Albuquerque]] became the second fiscal sponsor, providing an office in the historical [[Kimo Theater]] on [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]]. [[Steina and Woody Vasulka]] introduced the organizers to [[Godfrey Reggio]], director of the film [[Koyannisqatsi]] (1982) who provided guidance on organizing [[Social Sculpture]] events as ''[[public service announcements]]''. Reggio, having been involved in numerous progressive political causes, took interest because his Institute for Regional Education had developed a multi-media campaign of PSA's for the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] on the invasion of privacy and use of technology to control behavior in 1972. Grants were received from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] in the InterArts and the Artist Forums categories and the New Mexico Arts Division.
==External links== [https://vimeo.com/39454685 ART/MEDIA Documentation] https://vimeo.com/39454685
==See also== *[[Conceptual art]] *[[Ecofeminist art]] *[[Environmental art]] *[[Mass media]] *[[New media art]] *[[Performance art]] *[[Political art]] *[[Public art]] *[[Social sculpture]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:ART MEDIA}} [[Category:Art exhibitions in the United States]] [[Category:Sculpture exhibitions]] [[Category:Political art]] [[Category:Performance art festivals]] [[Category:Public art]]

Added a new musical theatre adaptation of Anna Karenina.
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Adaptations of ''Anna Karenina''}} This is a list of adaptations of ''[[Anna Karenina]]'', the novel by [[Leo Tolstoy]].
==Stage== * 1907: ''Anna Karénine'' by French playwright [[Edmond Guiraud]]. * 1937: ''Anna Karenina'' by Russian [[Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko]] * 1950s: a stage version of ''Anna Karenina'' has played at the Madach Theatre of Budapest. * 1992: ''Anna Karenina'' by English playwright [[Helen Edmundson]] and theatre company [[Shared Experience]]; an English stage adaptation of the novel which won London [[Time Out (magazine)|''Time Out'']] Award for Outstanding Theatrical Event of 1992. * 2008: ''Anna Karenina'' by Lithuanian director [[Eimuntas Nekrošius]], Italian production. * 2010: ''Anna Karenina'' by Ukrainian director and playwright [[Andriy Zholdak]]; a Finnish stage version of the novel. * 2012: ''Anna Karenina'' by American playwright Kevin McKeon and [[Portland Center Stage]] director Chris Coleman; an English stage version of the novel.
==Film== * 1911: ''Anna Karenina'', a French adaptation directed by Maurice André Maître.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anna Karenina (1911)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0210518/|publisher=IMDB}}</ref> * 1914: ''Anna Karenina'', a Russian adaptation directed by [[Vladimir Gardin]]. * 1915: [[Anna Karenina (1915 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1915 film)]], an American version starring Danish actress [[Betty Nansen]]. * 1918: [[Anna Karenina (1918 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1918 film)]], a Hungarian adaptation directed by [[Márton Garas]]. * 1927: [[Love (1927 American film)|''Love'' (1927 film)]], an American version, starring [[Greta Garbo]] and directed by [[Edmund Goulding]]. This version featured significant changes from the novel and had two different endings, with a happy one for American audiences. * 1935: [[Anna Karenina (1935 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1935 film)]], the most famous and critically acclaimed version, starring [[Greta Garbo]] and [[Fredric March]] and directed by [[Clarence Brown]]. * 1948: [[Anna Karenina (1948 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1948 film)]] starring [[Vivien Leigh]], [[Ralph Richardson]] and directed by [[Julien Duvivier]]. * 1953: [[Anna Karenina (1953 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1953 film)]], a Russian version directed by Tatyana Lukashevich. * 1954: ''[[Panakkaari]]'', a [[Tamil language]] adaptation directed by K. S. Gopalakrishnan * 1960: ''[[Nahr al-Hob]]'' (''River of Love''), an Egyptian movie directed by [[Ezzel Dine Zulficar]] * 1967: [[Anna Karenina (1967 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1967 film)]], a Russian version directed by [[Alexander Zarkhi]]. * 1976: ''Anna Karenina'', a Russian ballet version directed by Margarita Pilikhina. * 1985: [[Anna Karenina (1985 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1985 film)]], a U.S. TV movie starring [[Jacqueline Bisset]] and [[Christopher Reeve]], directed by [[Simon Langton (television director)|Simon Langton]]. * 1997: [[Anna Karenina (1997 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (1997 film)]], the first American version to be filmed on location in Russia, directed by [[Bernard Rose (director)|Bernard Rose]] and starring [[Sophie Marceau]] and [[Sean Bean]]. **see also [[Anna Karenina (soundtrack)|''Anna Karenina'' (soundtrack)]], the soundtrack of the 1997 film * 2012: [[Anna Karenina (2012 film)|''Anna Karenina'' (2012 film)]], a British version directed by [[Joe Wright]], starring [[Keira Knightley]].
==Radio== * 1944: A radio adaptation on [[The Screen Guild Theater]] starring [[Ingrid Bergman]] and [[Gregory Peck]]. Ingrid Bergman also did a [[Theater Guild on the Air]] adaptation in 1948. * 1949: Anna Karenina, ''[[The MGM Theater of the Air]]'' Radio Broadcast on 9 December 1949, starring [[Marlene Dietrich]]. * 1997: A four-part BBC radio production starring [[Toby Stephens]].
==Television== * 1961: [[Anna Karenina (TV programme)|''Anna Karenina'']], a [[BBC Television]] adaptation directed by [[Rudolph Cartier]], starring [[Claire Bloom]] and [[Sean Connery]].<ref name="karenina">{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/1181098/index.html|title=Cartier, Rudolph (1904–1994)|first=Oliver|last=Wake|publisher=[[Screenonline]]|accessdate=2007-02-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070301083011/http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/1181098/index.html| archivedate= 1 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="connery">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/7947501/Lost-BBC-period-drama-of-Anna-Karenina-found-starring-Sean-Connery.html|title=Lost BBC period drama of Anna Karenina found starring Sean Connery|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2010-08-17 | location=London | date=2010-08-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100820012415/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/7947501/Lost-BBC-period-drama-of-Anna-Karenina-found-starring-Sean-Connery.html| archivedate= 20 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} (It has been suggested [http://www.mausoleumclubforum.org.uk/xmb/viewthread.php?tid=21418] that reports of this sudden rediscovery [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11010927] are not entirely accurate as ''Anna Karenina'' has been available on DVD for a year in America.)</ref> * 1970s: A Cuban television series starring Margarita Balboa as Anna,<ref>[http://www.ecured.cu/index.php/Margarita_Balboa Cuban dramatic arts site]</ref> Miguel Navarro as Vronsky, and Angel Toraño as Karenin. * 1977: [[Anna Karenina (1977 TV serial)|''Anna Karenina'']], a 1977 ten-episode [[BBC]] series, directed by [[Basil Coleman]] and starred [[Nicola Pagett]], [[Eric Porter]] and [[Stuart Wilson (actor)|Stuart Wilson]].<ref>[https://us.imdb.com/title/tt0075476/ IMDb.com]</ref><ref>https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/masterpiece/archive/40/40.html</ref> * 2000: [[Anna Karenina (2000 miniseries)|''Anna Karenina'']], a four-part British TV adaptation made in 2000 directed by [[David Blair (director)|David Blair]]. Aired in America on [[PBS]] [[Masterpiece Theatre]] in 2001.<ref>https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/masterpiece/anna/</ref> * 2009: [[Anna Karenina (2009 TV mini-series)|''Anna Karenina'']], a Russian [[mini-series]] directed by [[Sergei Solovyov]]. * 2013: [[Anna Karenina (2013 TV series)|''Anna Karenina'']], a Filipino drama series directed by [[Gina Alajar]] * 2013: [[Anna Karenina (2013 film)|''Anna Karenina'']], an English-language Italian/French/Spanish/German/Lithuanian TV co-production by [[Christian Duguay (director)|Christian Duguay]] and starring [[Vittoria Puccini]], [[Benjamin Sadler]] and [[Santiago Cabrera]]. Alternatively presented as a two-part mini-series or a single 3 hours and 15 minutes film. * 2015: ''[[The Beautiful Lie (TV series)|The Beautiful Lie]]'', an Australian mini-series aired on the [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]].
==Ballet== * 2004: [[Anna Karenina (Shchedrin)|''Anna Karenina'']], a ballet choreographed by [[Alexei Ratmansky]], with music by [[Rodion Shchedrin]]. * 2005: [[Anna Karenina (Eifman)|''Anna Karenina'']], a Russian [[ballet]] choreographed by [[Boris Eifman]], with music by [[Tchaikovsky]]. * 2006: ''Anna Karenina'', a ballet in 3 acts choreographed by Terence Kohler, music from [[Shostakovich]], [[Rachmaninov]], [[Khachaturian]]. * 2014: ''Anna Karenina'', choreography by Christian Spuck (Ballett Zürich), with music mostly by [[Rachmaninoff]] and [[Witold Lutosławski|Lutosławski]]. * 2018: ''Anna Karenina'', a ballet by [[John Neumeier]] inspired by Leo Tolstoy; music by Tchaikovsky, [[Alfred Schnittke]] and [[Cat Stevens|Cat Stevens/Yusuf Islam]]<ref>https://national.ballet.ca/Productions/2018-19-Season/Anna-Karenina</ref> * 2019: ''Anna Karenina'', choreography by [[Yuri Possokhov]], music by [[Ilya Demutsky]]<ref>http://joffrey.org/anna</ref>
==Musical theatre== * 1992: ''[[Anna Karenina (musical)|Anna Karenina]]'', an ill-fated Broadway musical adaptation. * 1994: a [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] musical ''Anna Karenina'' composed by [[Tibor Kocsák]], lyrics by [[Tibor Miklós]] (renewed in 2008). *2016: Anna Karenina, an original Russian-language musical produced by the Moscow Operetta Theatre (live-recording filmed in 2018).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://karenina-musical.ru/en/|title=«Анна Каренина» мюзикл {{!}} Официальный сайт|website=1romantic|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
==Opera== * 1904-1905: ''[[Anna Karenina (Granelli)|Anna Karenina]]'' by Italian composer [[Edoardo Granelli]], composed in years 1904-1905. * 1905: ''[[Anna Karenina (Sassano)|Anna Karenina]]'' by Italian composer [[Salvatore Sassano]] on libretto by [[Antonio Menotti]]. Opera won a prize at the contest of the Institute for the Advancement of Music, [[Naples]] and was premièred by [[Mercadante Theater]] in Naples in 1905. * 1907: [[Leoš Janáček]] begun, but never finished the opera. * 1914: ''Anna Karénine'' by French composer [[Edmond Malherbe]], unperformed. * 1914: ''Karenina Anna'' by Hungarian composer [[Jenő Hubay]] on libretto by Sándor Góth and Andor Gábor based on 1907 [[Edmond Guiraud]]'s French dramatical adaptation. Premièred in 1923. * 1924: ''Anna Karenina'' by Italian [[verismo]] composer [[Igino Robbiani]] on libretto by [[Arturo Rosatto]], premièred 1924 at the [[Teatro Costanzi]] in [[Rome]]. * 1930: ''Anna Karenina'', op. 18 by Czech composer [[Stanislav Goldbach]] on libretto by [[Dalibor Chalupa]], composed 1927-1930. * 1970: ''Anna Karenina'' by Ukrainian composer [[Yuly Sergeyevich Meytus]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Classical Composers Database|url=http://www.classical-composers.org/comp/meytus}}</ref> * 1978: ''[[Anna Karenina (Hamilton)|Anna Karenina]]'' by Scottish composer [[Iain Hamilton (composer)|Iain Hamilton]] on his own libretto, premièred by [[English National Opera|ENO]] at the [[London Coliseum]] in 1981. * 2007: ''[[Anna Karenina (Carlson)|Anna Karenina]]'', an American opera with music by [[David Carlson]] on a libretto by [[Colin Graham]] which premiered in 2007 at [[Florida Grand Opera]]. Second version with an added scene on text by [[Mark Streshinsky]] was premièred in 2010 by [[Opera San Jose]].
==Popular music== * "Anna Karenina", a song by [[Nikos Xydakis (musician)|Nikos Xydakis]] and [[Thodoris Gonis]]. * "Not even Vronsky", a song by Natasha Luna.
==Literature== *''[[Android Karenina]]'', a [[Mashup (book)|mashup]] novel by [[Ben H. Winters]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Anna Karenina}}
[[Category:Adaptations of works by Leo Tolstoy]] [[Category:Literature lists]] [[Category:Works based on novels|Anna Karenina]] [[Category:Russian literature-related lists]]

{{italic title}} '''''American Gothic Tales''''' is an anthology of "gothic" American short fiction. Edited and with an Introduction by [[Joyce Carol Oates]], it was published by [[Plume (publisher)|Plume]] in 1996. It featured contributions by [[Washington Irving]], [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]], [[Edgar Allan Poe]], [[Stephen King]], [[Anne Rice]] and others, and included over 40 stories.<ref name="oates">[http://jco.usfca.edu/works/anthologies/gothic.html "A Joyce Carol Oates Home Page - Dust Jacket Blurb, Introduction, Contents"]</ref>
==Contents==
*Introduction *[[Charles Brockden Brown]]: ''[[Wieland (novel)|Wieland; or, the Transformation]]'' *[[Washington Irving]]: "[[The Legend of Sleepy Hollow]]" *[[Nathaniel Hawthorne]]: "[[The Man of Adamant]]" and "[[Young Goodman Brown]]" *[[Herman Melville]]: "[[Paradise of Bachelors and Tartarus of Maids|The Tartarus of Maids]]" *[[Edgar Allan Poe]]: "[[The Black Cat (short story)|The Black Cat]]" *[[Charlotte Perkins Gilman]]: "[[The Yellow Wallpaper]]" *[[Henry James]]: "[[The Romance of Certain Old Clothes]]" *[[Ambrose Bierce]]: "[[The Damned Thing (short story)|That Damned Thing]]" *[[Edith Wharton]]: "[[Afterward (short story)|Afterward]]" *[[Gertrude Atherton]]: "[[The Striding Place]]" *[[Sherwood Anderson]]: "[[Death in the Woods]]" *[[H. P. Lovecraft]]: "[[The Outsider (short story)|The Outsider]]" *[[William Faulkner]]: "[[A Rose for Emily]]" *[[August Derleth]]: "[[The Lonesome Place]]" *[[E. B. {{Infobox television | show_name = Artist of the Year | image = | genre = | show_name_2 = Portrait Artist of the Year
Landscape Artist of the Year | presenter = {{Plainlist| * [[Joan Bakewell]] * [[Frank Skinner]] * [[Stephen Mangan]] }} | judges = {{Plainlist| * [[Kate Bryan]] * [[Kathleen Soriano]] * [[Tai-Shan Schierenberg]] }} | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 7 | num_episodes = 61 | location = {{unbulleted list|Various (auditions)|[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] (finals)}} | runtime = 60 minutes (inc. adverts) | company = Storyvault Films | network = [[Sky Arts]] | picture_format = [[16:9]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|11|05|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{End date|present|df=yes}} }} '''''Artist of the Year''''' is a television competition shown on the [[Sky Arts]] channel (formerly known as Artsworld and Sky Arts 1) which aims to find the best portrait/landscape painter every year.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/tv-review-portrait-artist-of-the-year-sky-arts-1-8923377.html|title=TV Review: Portrait Artist of the Year, Sky Arts 1|publisher=[[The Independent]]|first=Ellen E.|last=Jones|date=6 November 2013|accessdate=21 June 2017}} Through several rounds of regional competitions in different parts of the UK professional and amateur artists are challenged to produce a portrait/landscape of one of three famous sitters. The winning artist of each round, selected by three judges, advances to the semifinal and then to the final, which are filmed at the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]]. The winner receives a £10,000 commission to paint a famous personality and the picture becomes part of a national gallery. The show is produced by London and Glasgow-based independent production company Storyvault Films. It is presented by the UK TV personalities [[Joan Bakewell]] and [[Frank Skinner]]. The judges are the British art historian, curator and arts broadcaster [[Kate Bryan]], head of contemporary art at the [[Fine Art Society]], [[Kathleen Soriano]], director of exhibitions at the [[Royal Academy]], and portrait/landscape painter [[Tai-Shan Schierenberg]]. ==Transmissions== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Series !! Start date !! End date !! Episodes !! Title |- | '''1''' || 5 November 2013 || 10 December 2013 || 6 || rowspan="2"| Portrait |- | '''2''' || 4 November 2014 || 23 December 2014 || 8 |- | '''3''' || 6 October 2015 || 1 December 2015 || 9 || rowspan="2"| Landscape |- | '''4''' || 11 October 2016 || 6 December 2016 || 9 |- | '''5''' || 24 January 2017 || 21 March 2017 || 9 || Portrait |- | '''6''' || 18 October 2017 || 10 December 2017 || 9 || Landscape |- | '''7''' || 16 January 2018 || 27 March 2018 || 11 || Portrait |- | '''8''' || 16 October 2018 || TBA 2018 || TBC || Landscape |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=4445396|title=Portrait Artist of the Year}} *{{IMDb title|id=5189210|title=Landscape Artist of the Year}} *{{Official website|https://www.skyartsartistoftheyear.tv/}} *{{UKGameshow|Artist_of_the_Year}} [[Category:2013 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2010s British reality television series]] [[Category:Sky television programmes]] [[Category:Television series about art]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

page.title: Association of Polish Artists and Designers

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Association of Polish Artists and Designers | image = ZPAP-Warsaw(Nowy-Swiat7).jpg | size = 260px | alt = ZPAP main office in Warsaw | caption = ZPAP main office in [[Warsaw]] | abbreviation = ZPAP | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | headquarters = Warsaw, kamienica Efrosa at ul. [[Nowy Świat]] 7 | coords = {{coord|52|14|30|N|21|00|56|E|}} | language = [[Polish language|Polish]] | leader_name = | former name = |www = http://www.zpap.org.pl }} The '''Association of Polish Artists and Designers''' ({{lang|pl|Związek Polskich Artystów Plastyków}}, ZPAP) is an official association of professional artists in [[Poland]], representing more than 8,500 learned artists working in the field of [[visual arts]], including: painting, sculpture, graphic design, interior and set design, ceramics, fabric arts, as well as new media, and [[art restoration]].
The Association was founded in 1911 in [[Kraków]] during the [[Partitions of Poland]]. In [[Polish culture in the Interbellum|the interwar period]] until 1939 it served as a trade union and in 1945, following World War II, it was formally re-established as an association.<ref>Glenn Sujo, [https://books.google.com/books?id=y7WuzDK3dSkC&pg=PA111&dq=ZPAP ''Legacies of Silence''.] Published by New Age Publishers, 2001; 127 pages. {{ISBN|0-85667-534-2}}.</ref><ref>[http://www.artluk.com/onas.php ''artluk'' Magazine] with funds by [[Ministry of Culture and National Heritage of the Republic of Poland|Polish Ministry of Culture and Art]]. {{en icon}} {{pl icon}}</ref> In 1980, ZPAP supported the [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity movement]] and opposed the imposition of [[Martial law in Poland|martial law in 1981]]. Consequently, the military authorities disbanded the Association when it refused to retract its [[communiqué]]s.<ref>Umbrella Magazine, [https://books.google.com/books?id=FGlUAAAAMAAJ&q=1982+%22The+suspension+of+ZPAP,+reported+by+the+official+press,+was+ordered+after+it+refused+to+retract+eight+communiques+released+in+the+last+year%22&dq=1982+%22The+suspension+of+ZPAP,+reported+by+the+official+press,+was+ordered+after+it+refused+to+retract+eight+communiques+released+in+the+last+year%22&pgis=1 Item notes: v. 5-7, page 68.] Published by Umbrella Associates, U.S., 1982</ref><ref>Joanna Inglot, [https://books.google.com/books?id=RnAaq6ws_kMC&pg=PA94&dq=%22the+majority+of+artists+joined+in+the+widespread+national+effort+to+break+the+party-state+monopoly%22#PPA95,M1 ''The Figurative Sculpture of Magdalena Abakanowicz''], page 95. Published by University of California Press, 2004; 154 pages. {{nobreak|{{ISBN|0-520-23125-2}}}}.</ref> ZPAP operated unofficially until the [[History of Poland (1989–present)|restoration of democracy]] in 1989. Today, ZPAP features prominently across the country with 23 regional Chapters, paid staff, curators, publications, and regional art galleries promoting work of its members.<ref name="IAM">Instytut Adama Mickiewicza, [http://www.culture.pl/pl/culture/artykuly/in_or_zpap "Sztuki wizualne: Związek Polskich Artystów Plastyków"] at www.culture.pl ISSN 1734-0624 Nr 2628</ref>
==Structure== ZPAP membership is limited to graduates of art faculties of relevant institutions of higher learning, with the main emphasis on regional Academies of Fine Arts. On top of its creative presence in major Polish cities, the Association operates two professional development retreats, in [[Ustka]] and in [[Świnoujście]].<ref name="IAM" /> It sponsors dozens of commercial art galleries across Poland as well as selected stores with professional art supplies. ZPAP organizes a number of annual events, and offers its own [[Jan Cybis]] Award for creative achievement. In 1996 the Association organized the UNESCO conference around the international status of an artist.<ref name="IAM" /> It is the leading advocacy group working in conjunction with the Polish governmental agencies regulating labor laws applicable to practising art professionals. ZPAP is represented in the World Executive Committee of the [[International Association of Art]] (IAA).<ref name="zpap.org">[http://www.zpap.org.pl/index.php?IdKat=1003010018&IdKat2=1157655602 Official webpage of The Association of Polish Artists and Designers] {{en icon}} {{pl icon}}</ref>
Since 1996, ZPAP manages copyrights of about 1,000 members and is in charge of issuing licenses for the commercial use of their artwork. The economic nonprofit activity of the Association is geared toward generating funds necessary for the maintaining of its venues, as well as providing financial support for members in need.<ref name="zpap.org"/>
The main office of ZPAP is in [[Warsaw]] and is located at the upper floor of the historic [[Kamienica (architecture)|kamienica]] Efrosa at [[Nowy Świat Street|ul. Nowy Świat]] 7 ''(pictured)'', where Princes of the [[Lubomirski family]] once lived in the 18th century. The building was rebuilt with its original [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] portal intact following wartime destruction of the Polish capital.<ref name="zpap.org"/>
Regional chapters of ZPAP are located in the following cities: [[Białystok]], [[Bielsko-Biała]], [[Bydgoszcz]], [[Częstochowa]], [[Gdańsk]], [[Katowice]], [[Kielce]], [[Koszalin]], [[Kraków]], [[Lublin]], [[Łódź]], [[Olsztyn]], [[Opole]], [[Poznań]], [[Radom]], [[Rzeszów]], [[Szczecin]], [[Toruń]], [[Warszawa]], [[Wrocław]], [[Zakopane]], [[Zielona Góra]], and [[Gliwice]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Art and design-related professional associations]] [[Category:Cultural organisations in Poland]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1911]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Bound | image = Bound movie poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[The Wachowskis]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Stuart Boros * [[Andrew Lazar]]}} | writer = The Wachowskis | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Jennifer Tilly]] * [[Gina Gershon]] * [[Joe Pantoliano]] * [[John P. Ryan (actor)|John Ryan]]}} | music = [[Don Davis (composer)|Don Davis]] | cinematography = [[Bill Pope]] | editing = [[Zach Staenberg]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Dino De Laurentiis|Dino De Laurentiis Company]] * [[Aaron Spelling|Spelling Group]] }} | distributor = [[Gramercy Pictures]]
(United States theatrical)
[[Summit Entertainment]]
(International) Republic Pictures(USA actual rights) | released = {{Film date|1996|08|31|[[Venice Film Festival]]|1996|10|04|US}} | runtime = 108 minutes{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/bound-1970-5 | title=''BOUND'' (18) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=September 20, 1996 | accessdate=June 6, 2015}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $6 million{{cite book | last =Marx | first =Christy | authorlink =Christy Marx | title =The Wachowski Brothers: Creators of the Matrix | publisher =The Rosen Publishing Group | year =2005 | url =https://www.google.com/books?id=ygTYcZrYPhcC&pg=PA19 | pages =19–21 | isbn =1-4042-0264-1 }} | gross = $7 million }} '''''Bound''''' is a 1996 American [[neo-noir]] [[Crime film|crime]] [[thriller film]] written and directed by [[the Wachowskis]] in their [[List of directorial debuts|feature film directorial debut]]. Violet ([[Jennifer Tilly]]), who longs to escape her relationship with her [[American Mafia|mafioso]] boyfriend Caesar ([[Joe Pantoliano]]), enters into a clandestine affair with alluring ex-con Corky ([[Gina Gershon]]), and the two women hatch a scheme to steal $2 million of mafia money. ''Bound'' was the first film directed by the Wachowskis, and they took inspiration from [[Billy Wilder]] to tell a noir story filled with sex and violence. Financed by [[Dino De Laurentiis]], the film was made on a tight budget with the help of frugal crew members including cinematographer [[Bill Pope]]. The directors initially struggled to cast the lesbian characters of Violet and Corky before securing Tilly and Gershon. To choreograph the sex scenes, the directors employed "sex educator" [[Susie Bright]], who also made a [[cameo appearance]] in the film. ''Bound'' received positive reviews from film critics who praised the humor and style of the directors as well as the realistic portrayal of a lesbian relationship in a mainstream film. Detractors of the film found its plot superficial and criticized the violence as excessive. The film won several festival awards. ==Plot== Corky ([[Gina Gershon]]), a lesbian ex-con who has just finished a five-year jail sentence, arrives at an apartment building to start work as a painter and plumber. On her way up to the apartment, she encounters the couple who live next-door, Violet ([[Jennifer Tilly]]) and Caesar ([[Joe Pantoliano]]). After Caesar has gone out, Violet flirts with Corky and asks her to help retrieve an earring that has fallen down her sink. After Corky extracts the earring, Violet admits she lost it on purpose in order to get closer to Corky, and starts to seduce her. They are interrupted by the arrival of Caesar and Corky goes back to work. When she leaves for the day, Violet follows her to her truck. They go to Corky's apartment and have sex. The next morning, Violet tells Corky that Caesar is a money launderer for the Mafia and they have been together for five years. Later, Violet overhears Caesar and his Mafia associates beating and torturing Shelly ([[Barry Kivel]]), a man who has been skimming money from the business. Upset by the violence and cruelty, Violet seeks solace from Corky. She tells Corky that she wants to make a new life for herself, but that she needs her help. Knowing that Caesar will find the nearly $2 million Shelly took and count it in their apartment, the two women hatch a scheme to steal the money. Corky, already wary of Violet's intentions, is unsure whether to trust her. Shelly is shot and killed by Johnnie ([[Christopher Meloni]]), the son of Mafia boss Gino Marzzone ([[Richard C. Sarafian]]), and Caesar returns to the apartment with a bag of bloody money. Angry at Johnnie for killing Shelly in a fit of rage and splattering blood everywhere, Caesar proceeds to wash, iron and hang the money to dry. Violet explains to Corky that Caesar and Johnnie hate each other, and that Gino and Johnnie will be coming to pick up the money from Caesar. The plan is as follows: When Caesar has finished counting the money, Violet will get him a drink to relax him before he showers. Corky will be next-door, waiting until she hears Caesar turn on the shower. When he does, Violet will drop the bottle of Scotch that is for Gino and tell Caesar that she is going to buy more. As she leaves the apartment, she will let Corky in, who will steal the money from a briefcase and leave. Violet will then return with the Scotch and tell Caesar that she just saw Johnnie leaving, but that Gino was not with him. Suspicious, Caesar will check the briefcase, find the money gone, and assume Johnnie has taken it. Corky and Violet think Caesar will be forced to skip town because Gino will assume he has been robbed by Caesar, not his son. Everything goes as planned until Caesar finds the money gone. He realizes that if he runs, Gino will think he took the money. He decides he has to get the money back from Johnnie. Panicking, Violet threatens to leave. Caesar pulls out his gun and forces her to stay, thinking that maybe she and Johnnie have stolen the money and framed him. Corky waits next-door with the money while Gino and Johnnie arrive. After watching Johnnie flirt with Violet and taunt him, Caesar pulls out a gun and tells Gino that his son stole the money. In an angry panic, he kills both Gino and Johnnie, and Gino's bodyguard Roy. He tells Violet that they have to find the money, dispose of the bodies, and pretend Gino and Johnnie never arrived, lest their Mafia pals find the money or men missing. Unable to find the money at Johnnie's apartment, Caesar telephones Mickey ([[John P. Ryan (actor)|John P. Ryan]]), a Mafia friend, telling him that Gino has yet to arrive. After discovering Corky and Violet stole the money, Caesar ties them up, gags them, threatens to torture them, and demands to know where it is. When Mickey arrives to see what is going on, Caesar, panicked, makes a deal with Violet to help him stall. As he prepares to kill Mickey, Violet calls the landline from Johnnie's cell phone and quickly convinces Caesar to pretend that he's on the phone with Gino, who's calling from a hospital to explain that he and Johnnie were in a car accident. Mickey is convinced and leaves for the hospital. Corky tells Caesar where she has hidden the money, and he goes next-door to find it. Violet escapes and makes a phone call to Mickey, telling him that Caesar stole the money and forced her to keep quiet. In the meantime, Corky tries to stop Caesar from taking the money, but he beats her to the ground. Just as he is about to kill her, Violet arrives and pulls a gun on Caesar, telling him that Mickey is on his way and that he should run while he can. Caesar tells Violet that he knows she will not shoot him, to which she replies, "Caesar, you don't know shit", before killing him. Later, Mickey, who believes Violet's story, tells her that he will find Caesar, and that there is no need to involve the police. Mickey wants Violet to be his girlfriend, but she tells him that she needs a clean break—which she makes by driving off hand-in-hand with Corky. ==Cast== * [[Gina Gershon]] as Corky * [[Jennifer Tilly]] as Violet * [[Joe Pantoliano]] as Caesar * [[Mary Mara]] as Bartender * [[Susie Bright]] as Jesse * [[Margaret Smith (comedian)|Margaret Smith]] as Woman Cop * [[Barry Kivel]] as Shelly * [[Christopher Meloni]] as Johnnie Marzzone * [[John P. Ryan (actor)|John Ryan]] as Mickey Malnato * [[Peter Spellos]] as Lou * Ivan Kane as Cop #1 * [[Kevin Michael Richardson|Kevin M. Richardson]] as Cop #2 * [[Richard C. Sarafian]] as Gino Marzzone * Gene Borkan as Roy ==Background and production== ===Conception=== Film producer [[Joel Silver]] has said that after working as scriptwriters on ''[[Assassins (film)|Assassins]]'', the Wachowskis made ''Bound'' as an "audition piece" to prove that they knew what to do on a movie set. Conversely, Lana Wachowski has said Joel "made that up." The Wachowskis themselves claim they "decided simply to focus on making their own directorial debut."{{cite web | last =Vary | first=Adam | title = The Wachowskis Refuse To Take No For An Answer | work =BuzzFeed | url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/adambvary/the-wachowskis-jupiter-ascending-the-matrix-cloud-atlas | date = February 6, 2015 | accessdate =August 31, 2015}} They had the idea to write a story about how one might see a woman on the street and make assumptions about her sexuality, but how those assumptions might be wrong.{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Josh |title=The Lost Wachowski Brothers Interview |work=MoviePoopShoot.com |url=http://www.moviepoopshoot.com/interviews/27.html |date=November 5, 2003 |accessdate=March 9, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031202184946/http://www.moviepoopshoot.com/interviews/27.html |archivedate=December 2, 2003 }} They wanted to play with stereotypes and make an entertaining film that contained sex and violence, because those are the kinds of films that they like to watch. Seeing [[film noir]] as a genre within which they could tell a contained story and twist conventions, they described [[Billy Wilder]] as a big influence. When executives at some studios read the script, they told the Wachowskis that if they changed the character of Corky to that of a man, they would be interested. The siblings declined, saying "that movie's been made a million times, so we're really not interested in it."{{Cite journal|last=Whilk |first=Nat |last2=Whitehead |first2=Jayson |title=Glory Bound: An interview with Larry and Andy Wachowski |work=[[Gadfly Online]] |publisher=Gadfly Productions |date=January 1998 |url=http://www.gadflyonline.com/archive-wachowski.html |accessdate=June 5, 2007 |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040301035225/http://www.gadflyonline.com/archive-wachowski.html |archivedate=March 1, 2004 |df= }} [[Dino De Laurentiis]], the executive producer on ''Assassins'', offered to finance ''Bound'' and his company produced it, giving them "free rein" with regard to the story.{{cite video |people=[[Wachowskis]], [[Joe Pantoliano]], [[Jennifer Tilly]], [[Gina Gershon]], [[Susie Bright]] |title=Director/Writers/actors Commentary |type = [[DVD]] |publisher=[[Gramercy Pictures]] |date=1997}} The film's budget was $6 million. ===Casting=== The Wachowskis struggled to cast the roles of Violet and Corky, seemingly because of the lesbian content of the film. Few actresses were interested. The part of Violet was expected to go to [[Linda Hamilton]], and Jennifer Tilly read for the part of Corky. She loved the role and was looking forward to playing a character very different from previous parts in her career.{{Cite journal | last =Vincent | first =Mal | title = Tilly is no Shrinking Violet in "Bound" | work =[[The Virginian-Pilot]] | publisher =[[Landmark Media Enterprises]] | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080506144714/http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/VA-news/VA-Pilot/issues/1996/vp961107/11070036.htm | archivedate =May 6, 2008 | date =July 11, 1996 | url =http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/VA-news/VA-Pilot/issues/1996/vp961107/11070036.htm | accessdate =March 8, 2010 | postscript = }} When the part of Violet became available, and Gina Gershon came in to read for Corky, Tilly agreed that Gershon would make a better Corky.{{Cite journal|last=Harkness |first=John |title=Jennifer Tilly — Noir thriller brings versatile actor out of ingenue ghetto |work=[[Now (newspaper)|NOW]] |publisher=NOW Communications Inc |date=October 1996 |url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/issues/16/05/Ent/cover.html |accessdate=November 7, 2007 |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926224440/http://www.nowtoronto.com/issues/16/05/Ent/cover.html |archivedate=September 26, 2007 |df= }} She realized that she identified with the character of Violet, a woman "underestimated by all the men around her" who has to "play the game".{{Cite journal | last =Stagg Elliott | first =Victoria | title = Bound to Please | work =[[Diva (magazine)|Diva]] | publisher =Millivres Prowler Group Ltd | date =March 1997 | url =http://www.bound.ch/diva.htm | accessdate =June 19, 2007 | postscript = }} She describes it as the best role she had ever had. Gina Gershon suggested Joe Pantoliano to the Wachowskis for the part of Caesar.{{cite web|title=INTERVIEW WITH JOE PANTOLIANO (PART 2 OF 2)|date=4 April 2001|publisher=[[IGN]]|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/04/04/interview-with-joe-pantoliano-part-2-of-2|accessdate=6 February 2017}} His first lead role in a film, he describes it as his favorite.{{cite web | last =Morris | first =Clint | authorlink =Clint Morris | title = Joe Pantoliano: Exclusive Interview | work =WebWombat.com | publisher =WebWombat Pty Ltd | url =http://www.webwombat.com.au/entertainment/movies/badboys_int.htm | accessdate =June 5, 2007 }} ===Filming=== ''Bound'' was shot in thirty-eight days in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], California. The Wachowskis' original [[Cinematographer|director of photography]] resigned on the grounds that he could not do the film with the limited budget he had available, nor did he know anyone he believed could. Subsequently, cinematographer [[Bill Pope]] was hired, who knew "a bunch of cheap guys".{{cite web|last=Lamm |first=Spencer |title=Bill Pope |work=The Matrix official site |url=http://whatisthematrix.warnerbros.com/cmp/pope_int.html |accessdate=June 5, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108121657/http://whatisthematrix.warnerbros.com/cmp/pope_int.html |archivedate=January 8, 2009 }} Pope became heavily involved in creating the visual noir style of the film. He and the Wachowskis drew from their love of comics and were influenced by [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller's]] neo-noir ''[[Sin City]]'' series in particular. Pope's sound counterpart was sound director [[Dane Davis]]. One of his ideas was to give Corky a [[cat]]-like quality by making a "swishing" sound every time she walks past the camera in the scene where she and Violet plan the theft. The Wachowskis asked Joe Pantoliano to watch [[John Huston]]'s ''[[The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (film)|The Treasure of the Sierra Madre]]'' and to focus on [[Humphrey Bogart]]'s character in order to prepare the paranoia of Caesar. Gershon's influences for her role were [[James Dean]], [[Marlon Brando]] and [[Clint Eastwood]]. Both Gershon and Tilly were nervous about filming the sex scenes and prepared by drinking [[tequila]]. Very little improvisation took place during the filming due to the directors' extensive planning and clear vision for the film. Not everything went as expected, however, as the physical exchanges in the script caused some injuries. Barry Kivel, whose character Shelly was violently beaten in Caesar's bathroom, received a head injury from his head being banged against the toilet. In the scenes between Corky and Caesar near the end of the film, Gina Gershon hit her hand so hard when she knocked a gun from Joe Pantoliano's hand that she required [[surgical suture|stitches]]. ===Sex scenes=== The sex scenes were choreographed by feminist writer and sex educator [[Susie Bright]]. The Wachowskis were fans of Bright and sent her a copy of the script with a letter asking her to be an extra in the film. When she read the script she loved it, particularly as it was about women enjoying having sex and not apologizing for it. Disappointed that they never described exactly what was happening in the sex scenes, she asked if she could be a sex consultant for the film and they agreed. The main sex scene set in Corky's apartment was filmed in one long shot. The Wachowskis believed that this would look more realistic than several shots edited together. Although it should have been a closed set, there were actually many people present, moving the walls of the set in order to allow full movement of the camera around the actors. Bright appeared as Jesse, the woman Corky tries to talk to in the bar. Comedian [[Margaret Smith (comedian)|Margaret Smith]] played Jesse's girlfriend and the extras in the bar scene were Bright's friends—"real life San Francisco [[Dyke (slang)|dykes]]". ==Themes== The Wachowskis describe several themes present in ''Bound''. They say that the film is about "the boxes people make of their lives", that it is not only gay people who "live in [[Closeted|closets]]". They wanted to define all of ''Bound'''s characters by the "sort of trap that they were making out of their lives". Violet is trapped in her life with Caesar, and in the first scene, Corky is literally inside Violet's closet, bound and gagged by Caesar. This scene is echoed later in the film when Violet says "I had this image of you inside of me..." This theme of being trapped is exacerbated by the claustrophobic feeling created by the fact that most of the film takes place in Corky's apartment, Violet and Casear's apartment, or the apartment next door where Corky is working. Susie Bright described some of the specifically lesbian themes of the film. One is the concept of the hand as a sex organ, highlighted by lingering camera shots of Corky and Violet's hands. Another is the repeated use of water as a symbolic [[Motif (visual arts)|motif]] to represent women, present for example when Corky is retrieving Violet's earring from the sink. Bright describes it as a movie that is "wet" (feminine) as opposed to "hard" (masculine). She says the scene where Corky and Violet have their first conversation is full of "lesbian signs". She highlights the fact that Violet, away from Caesar, is wearing jeans and able to be less overtly feminine. Jennifer Tilly says that whenever Violet is talking to men, her voice becomes high-pitched and "girly"—making her seem vulnerable and ensuring she is taken care of. Joe Pantoliano agrees, saying that the result is that "everyone in the film wants to be with Violet". When she is with Corky, Violet can drop the act and talk at a more natural pitch. According to Bright, the more subtle lesbian themes of the film were noticed and appreciated at the [[LGBT]] film festival screenings. ==Release== ===Rating=== ''Bound'' was rated by the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA) as R for "strong sexuality, violence and language." To achieve that rating, the directors had to cut part of the first sex scene between Corky and Violet. The MPAA were most concerned with the images of what Lana Wachowski called "hand-sex".{{cite book | last =Merck | first =Mandy | title =In Your Face: 9 Sexual Studies | publisher =NYU Press | year =2000 | pages =124–147 | isbn =0-8147-5639-5 }} It was rated R in Australia, R18 in New Zealand and 18 in the United Kingdom. In Canada it was rated as R in [[Manitoba]] and [[Ontario]], 18 in [[Nova Scotia]] and 16+ in [[Quebec]]. ===Distribution=== The film [[premiere]]d on August 31, 1996, at the [[Venice Film Festival]] and in September went on to play at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]]. It opened in U.S. theaters on October 4, 1996 distributed by [[Gramercy Pictures]], showing in 261 theaters.{{cite web| title = Bound| publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]]| url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=bound.htm| accessdate = May 9, 2007}} It closed after three weeks. It opened in the United Kingdom on February 28, 1997.{{cite web | title =Bound (1996) | publisher =Cinema.com | url =http://www.cinema.com/film/2012/bound/index.phtml | accessdate = August 22, 2007 }} ===Box office=== ''Bound'' grossed $3,802,260 in the United States and $3,209,057 from other territories, for a worldwide total of $7,011,317. In its opening weekend, showing at 261 theaters, it earned $900,902, which was 23.7% of its total gross. According to [[Box Office Mojo]], it ranked at 161 for all films released in the United States in 1996, and at 74 for R-rated films released that year. {{as of|2012|July}}, its all-time ranking for [[LGBT]]-related films is 59. ===Critical response=== The review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave it a positive rating of 93% based on 40 reviews, while [[Metacritic]] gave it a score of 61/100 based on 19 reviews.{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bound/ |title=Bound |accessdate=July 8, 2012 |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/bound|title=Bound |accessdate=May 9, 2007 |publisher=MetaCritic}} The Wachowskis' direction was praised, being described as clever, sophisticated and stylish.{{Cite news | last =Kempley | first =Rita | title ='Bound' for Gory | newspaper =[[The Washington Post]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/review96/boundkemp.htm | postscript = }}{{Cite news | last = Schwarzbaum | first =Lisa | title =Girlie Movie | newspaper =[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date =October 11, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,294522,00.html | postscript = }}{{cite web | last =Levy | first =Emanuel | authorlink =Emanuel Levy | title =Bound | work =EmanuelLevy.com | url =http://emanuellevy.com/article.php?articleID=2534 | accessdate =May 29, 2007 }} [[Roger Ebert]] said that their skillful film making showed virtuosity and confidence.{{Cite news | last =Ebert | first =Roger | author-link =Roger Ebert | title =Bound | newspaper =[[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate = May 28, 2007 | url =http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19961004/REVIEWS/610040302/1023 | postscript = }} Marjorie Baumgarten writing for ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' called it an impressive debut saying that the Wachowskis have "style to burn".{{Cite news | last =Baumgarten | first =Marjorie | title =Bound | newspaper =[[The Austin Chronicle]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Calendar/Film?Film=oid%3a138033 | postscript = }} James Kendrick called it a darkly comical and stunning film, saying it signalled the arrival of the Wachowskis on the film scene.{{cite web | last =Kendrick | first =James | title =Bound | work =QNetwork | url =http://www.qnetwork.com/?page=review&id=133 | accessdate =May 29, 2007 }} Detractors of the film included Todd McCarthy for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', who said that the directors had no sense of humor and lacked depth, that the film was pretentious, superficial and heavy-handed.{{Cite news | last =McCarthy | first =Todd | title =Bound | newspaper =[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date =January 26, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=review&reviewid=VE1117904897&CS=1 | postscript = }} On the release of ''Bound'', the Wachowskis were compared by many to the [[Coen Brothers]].{{Cite news | last = Maslin | first = Janet | author-link =Janet Maslin | title = Girl Meets Girl. Dumps Boy. | newspaper =[[The New York Times]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://movies2.nytimes.com/mem/movies/review.html?title1=BOUND%20%28MOVIE%29&reviewer=By%20JANET%20MASLIN&pdate=19961004| postscript = }} Rita Kempley for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' went so far as to call them "Coen Brothers clones". In particular, similarities were drawn between ''Bound'' and the Coen Brothers' first film, 1984 neo-noir ''[[Blood Simple]]''.{{Cite news | last = Newman | first = Kim | author-link =Kim Newman | title =Bound | newspaper =[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire Magazine]] | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url = http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=131896 | postscript = }}{{Cite news|last=Thomas |first=Kevin |title=Bound |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 4, 1996 |accessdate=May 28, 2007 |url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-movie961028-45,0,1355383.story |postscript= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403165028/http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-movie961028-45%2C0%2C1355383.story |archivedate=April 3, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Bryant Frazer for ''Deep Focus'' called it an "obvious precursor".{{cite web | last =Frazer | first =Bryant | title =Bound | work =Deep Focus | url =http://www.deep-focus.com/flicker/bound.html | accessdate =May 29, 2007 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20120207012130/http://www.deep-focus.com/flicker/bound.html# | archive-date =February 7, 2012 | dead-url =yes | df =mdy-all }} Critics noted resemblances to the films of [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Alfred Hitchcock]].{{Cite news | last = Schickel | first = Richard | author-link =Richard Schickel | title =No Gag | newspaper =[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date =October 27, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,985288,00.html | postscript = }}{{Cite news | last =LaSalle | first =Mick | author-link =Mick LaSalle | title =Darkly Witty 'Bound' a Taut Noir Caper | newspaper =[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate = May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1996/10/04/DD42774.DTL | postscript = }} Janet Maslin for ''[[The New York Times]]'' said that the grisly violence in ''Bound'' would likely limit its audience and Ebert said that its shocking violence would offend some audiences. Some critics said that the violent behavior of the characters had no moral justification. Rita Kempley for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called it "well-nigh unwatchable cruelty for its own sake". McCarthy, who called the central relationship between the two women unbelievable and unsympathetic, said "just because Violet and Corky fall for each other doesn't mean they somehow fall into a privileged state of grace in which vile behavior can be forgiven." Other critics were less concerned, calling the violence "comically excessive" and "Tarantino-like". ''Bound'' was praised for being perhaps the first mainstream film to have a [[lesbian]] relationship at its heart without [[homosexuality]] being central to the plot.{{cite web|last=Warn |first=Sarah |authorlink=Sarah Warn |title=Review of "Bound" |work=[[AfterEllen.com and TheBacklot.com|AfterEllen.com]] |date=June 6, 2003 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/Movies/bound.html |accessdate=May 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070601233424/http://www.afterellen.com/Movies/bound.html |archivedate=June 1, 2007 |df= }} Despite the presence of "unapologetically gay" lead character Corky, it is not commonly considered a "lesbian movie".{{Cite news | last =Fowler | first =Jimmy | title =Dynamic duo | newspaper =[[Dallas Observer]] | date =October 3, 1996 | accessdate = May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.dallasobserver.com/1996-10-03/film/dynamic-duo/ | postscript = }} Emanuel Levy said that this is a weakness, that mainstream films with broadening storylines "do not necessarily represent a positive development in the making of gay and lesbian films" and that ''Bound'' has "little, if anything, to do with lesbian cinema". [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] for the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' called it a "welcome change" to have a lesbian couple as the main characters in a mainstream film.{{Cite news | last =Rosenbaum | first =Jonathan | author-link =Jonathan Rosenbaum | title =Bound | newspaper =[[Chicago Reader]] | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://onfilm.chicagoreader.com/movies/capsules/13817_BOUND | postscript = }} [[Sarah Warn]] for [[AfterEllen.com and TheBacklot.com|AfterEllen.com]] called Corky "the closest thing to a realistic and sympathetic butch lesbian we've seen in a mainstream movie". Barry Walters for the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' praised the film for showing gay characters that have an active sex life.{{Cite news | last =Walters | first =Barry | title =Sexy, funny, fast-paced film is "Bound' to please | newspaper =[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date =October 4, 1996 | accessdate =May 28, 2007 | url =http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1996/10/04/WEEKEND7240.dtl | postscript = }} The sex scenes, described as explicit and steamy, were admired for being tasteful, discreet and realistic. Warn called them "some of the best lesbian sex scenes to date in a mainstream movie". The three lead actors were complimented for their performances. Ebert said that Gershon and Tilly were electric together, and Frazer said that he would have liked to have seen more of their love story. Some critics described their onscreen relationship as unbelievable and unsympathetic. Gershon was seen to have made a comeback after her role in the less well received 1995 film ''[[Showgirls (film)|Showgirls]]''. Tilly's performance was compared to her [[Academy Award]]-nominated part in ''[[Bullets Over Broadway]]''. Pantoliano was described as "a lot of fun" and having the "trickiest scenes in the movie".{{cite web|last=Null |first=Christopher |authorlink=Christopher Null |title=Bound |work=Filmcritic.com |url=http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/ddb5490109a79f598625623d0015f1e4/7021523c3bc32540862563b000818aef?OpenDocument |accessdate=May 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071105174049/http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/ddb5490109a79f598625623d0015f1e4/7021523c3bc32540862563b000818aef?OpenDocument |archivedate=November 5, 2007 |df= }} ===Accolades=== ''Bound'' won the Grand Jury Award—Honorable Mention at the 1996 [[Outfest|L.A. Outfest]], and in the same year won an Honorable Mention at the [[Stockholm International Film Festival]].{{cite web | coauthors = | title =The Wachowski Brothers Biography | work =Tribute.ca | url =http://www.tribute.ca/people/bio/10799 | accessdate =July 12, 2007 }}{{cite web|title=1996 Year's Winners |work=Stockholm International Film Festival |url=http://www.filmfestivalen.se/1996/press.html |accessdate=July 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070602192504/http://www.filmfestivalen.se/1996/press.html |archivedate=June 2, 2007 |df= }} At the 1997 [[Fantasporto]] festival in Portugal, the Wachowskis were awarded the International Fantasy Film Award for best film, and Jennifer Tilly picked up the award for best actress.{{cite web |title=Fantasporto Awards |work=www.caleida.pt |url=http://www.caleida.pt/fantasporto/2006/en/aleph/envelope?subseccao+ficha:list_subseccao:24+listagem:list_subseccao:seccao:5 |doi= |accessdate=July 12, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629215309/http://www.caleida.pt/fantasporto/2006/en/aleph/envelope?subseccao+ficha%3Alist_subseccao%3A24+listagem%3Alist_subseccao%3Aseccao%3A5 |archivedate=June 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} ''Bound'' won the 1997 [[GLAAD Media Award]] for Outstanding (wide-release) Film. The film was nominated for the prestigious [[Grand Prix (Belgian Film Critics Association)|Grand Prix]] of the [[Belgian Film Critics Association|Belgian Syndicate of Cinema Critics]].{{cite news|url=http://archives.lesoir.be/musique_t-19970113-Z0D5V2.html|title="Drifting Clouds", Prix de l'UCC|journal=[[Le Soir]]|date=January 13, 1997|page=9|accessdate=October 27, 2012|language=French}} ===Home media=== ''Bound'' was released on Region 1 [[DVD]] on November 12, 1997 by [[Republic Pictures]]. It featured the original theatrical [[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]] and an [[audio commentary]] by the directors and stars.{{cite web|title=Bound |publisher=MovieWeb.com |url=http://www.movieweb.com/dvd/release/55/13955/features.php |accessdate=July 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181318/http://www.movieweb.com/dvd/release/55/13955/features.php |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }} It was released on Region 2 DVD on August 25, 2003, by [[Pathé Distribution|Pathé]] featuring original theatrical trailers, audio commentary by the directors and stars, cast and crew biographies and a production [[featurette]].{{cite web | title =Bound (1997): DVD | publisher =[[Amazon.co.uk]] | url =https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bound-Jennifer-Tilly/dp/B00004D0C4//026-5266876-5617257 | accessdate =August 22, 2007 }} Its Region 4 DVD release, distributed by Reel and featuring an audio commentary, came on August 14, 2006.{{cite web|title=Bound |publisher=EzyDVD |url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/item.zml/788183 |accessdate=August 22, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927004641/http://www.ezydvd.com.au/item.zml/788183 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df= }} ==Music== The [[Film score|score]], composed by [[Don Davis (composer)|Don Davis]], was given a promotional release on November 25, 1997 by Super Tracks Music Group, but has never been released commercially.{{cite web | title =Bound | publisher =FilmTracks.com | url =http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/bound.html | accessdate =July 12, 2007 }} Having her character Corky play a [[Jew's harp|jaw harp]] was Gina Gershon's idea. The directors' budget for songs was small; they had wanted to use "[[The Girl from Ipanema]]" and [[Frank Sinatra]] songs, but could not afford to. The four songs used in the film were not included on the score release.{{cite web | title =Bound Soundtrack | work =SoundTrackInfo.com | url =http://www.soundtrackinfo.com/ost.asp?soundtrack=3033 | accessdate =July 12, 2007 }} # "[[I Never Loved a Man (The Way I Love You) (song)|I Never Loved a Man (The Way I Love You)]]" ([[Ronny Shannon]]) performed by [[Aretha Franklin]] # "[[Hallelujah I Love Her So]]" ([[Ray Charles]]) performed by Ray Charles #
